entry.title: Session 2 Recap & Highlights– Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott
entry.content:
The session started with Irfan doing a quick round up of SAP BDC starting with the Why? behind the launch of Business Data Cloud. Irfan pointed a fundamental problem: businesses spend approximately 82% of their time on data curation & manipulation rather than business transformation. Here, SAP Business Data Cloud emerges as a revolutionary solution, designed to flip this paradigm by providing a modern Lake House architecture that harmonizes data across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Irfan highlighted that the key breakthrough of BDC is its approach to data products. By the end of 2024, SAP plans to offer around 500 data products, each representing intricate details of various business applications. The push logic mechanism allows seamless data ingestion from core ERP systems, creating a more efficient and intelligent data management ecosystem.

During the Q&A session, Timo Elliott skillfully extracted critical insights from Khan. One pivotal discussion revolved around data quality - a perennial challenge in enterprise computing to which Irfan candidly acknowledged that while AI can help improve data matching and cleanup, organizations must still institutionalize robust data governance practices.

Irfan talked about importance of knowledge graphs - a technology that enables more nuanced, context-aware data interactions. By using vertices and edges to identify patterns and similarities, knowledge graphs can answer complex, open-ended business questions that traditional SQL interfaces cannot.  Irfan also talked about SAP BDC being an open platform designed to work with various data sources and technologies. The partnership with Databricks, for instance, demonstrates SAP's commitment to providing flexible, interoperable solutions.

 Here are some key highlights from the Q&A session between Timo Elliott and Irfan Khan:

  1. Timo: What are the key technologies in Business Data Cloud that you're most proud of?

Irfan's highlighted the foundation service built on a modern Lake House architecture, with a unique push logic for data ingestion. He was particularly excited about creating a data product hierarchy that has been open-sourced on GitHub, allowing customers and partners to build their own data products already.

  1. Timo: What makes intelligent applications different from previous analytics applications?

Irfan's emphasized 3 key differences:

  • The integration of agents as an integral part of the applications
  • Ensuring that these applications are grounded in reliable, high-quality data with preserved business context
  • The ability to create more functionally rich applications that can curate data from both SAP and non-SAP sources
  1. Timo: How do customers with existing SAP data platforms like BW or HANA transition to Business Data Cloud?

Irfan explained that  customers have multiple options:

  • They can semantically onboard their existing data products into BDC
  • For BW systems, this could mean modernizing by bringing in data and building AI/ML capabilities on top of curated data products
  • There's flexibility to run existing systems in parallel with BDC
  1. Timo: How is SAP addressing data quality, a long-standing challenge?

Irfan acknowledged that data quality remains a complex issue. While AI can help with tasks like address matching, organizations must still:

  • Institutionalize data governance
  • Use proper master data management tools
  • Ensure data quality before implementation projects
  • Leverage BDC's capabilities to provide curated, semantically enriched data

As the webcast drew to a close, the conversation between Timo Elliott and Irfan Khan crystallized a powerful message for enterprise architects: we are standing at the precipice of a transformative era in Data and Artificial Intelligence. SAP Business Data Cloud is not just a technological solution, but a strategic capability that empowers organizations to transcend traditional data limitations. By harmonizing SAP and non-SAP data, embedding intelligent agents, and providing a robust, flexible architecture, SAP is offering more than a product – it's providing a vision of how businesses can truly unlock the potential of their data. For enterprise architects, this represents an unprecedented opportunity to move from being mere technology managers to becoming strategic innovators who can reshape how organizations understand, interact with, and derive value from their most critical asset: their data. The future is not about managing data; it's about orchestrating intelligence. To all the Enterprise Architects attending the session, the message was clear: the future belongs to those who can effectively harmonize data, leverage AI, and create intelligent, context-aware systems.

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below: https://go4.events.sap.com/shift-eaa-bdc-webinar/en_us/home.html

entry.title: Quickly Deploy a Streamlit Python App to BTP
entry.content:
Streamlit is an open-source Python framework that is useful for quickly building and deploying data-centric web apps with dynamic frontends (link to documentation). A key benefit of using Streamlit is that AI scientists/engineers can create UI-based apps using just Python (a language they tend to be highly familiar with), rather than having to resort to JavaScript, HTML/CSS, etc. Streamlit use cases may include analytics dashboards that leverage Pandas data frames, visualization of geographical maps, and interactive ML services (see many more examples in the Streamlit app gallery here).

In this blog post, we will look at how to quickly deploy a Streamlit app on BTP, which can be especially useful for productizing company-internal data products. Fortunately, this SAP tutorial already describes how to deploy a "Hello World" Python app on BTP using Cloud Foundry, and we will use that tutorial as a basis for rest of this blog post. While that tutorial uses the Flask framework, we only need to make a few small modifications to the code to make it work for Streamlit. As such, in the following, we will assume that you are able to deploy the "Hello World" Flask app from that tutorial without any issues.

In order to modify the tutorial code to work with Streamlit, perform the following changes:

In server.py, replace all of the code with:

import streamlit as st

st.write("Hello world")

In requirements.txt, add the following requirement:

streamlit

In manifest.yml, change the line describing the command to:

command: streamlit run server.py --server.port 8080

Notice that the Streamlit app is exposed on port 8080.

And that's essentially it 😊

Now redeploy the app with cf push.

The app should load at the appropriate app url (e.g., https://<some_url_prefix>.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/).

entry.title: Unlocking Data Potential: What I Learned from SAP Sapphire
entry.content:
Unlocking Data Potential: What I Learned from SAP Sapphire

Hi everyone! I’m Kara Reed, Senior Director of Product Marketing at SAP. At this year’s SAP Sapphire, I had the privilege of co-presenting a session with Brian Suk from Databricks on a topic that’s very close to my heart: how organizations can unlock the full value of their data through the combined power of SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks.

Our session—" SAP and Databricks open a bold new era of data and AI"—highlighted how businesses can build trusted, AI-powered applications with SAP Databricks, a fully SAP-managed solution that combines industry leading AI/ML, data science, and data engineering capabilities with semantically rich, business-ready data from SAP applications. Let me take you behind the scenes and share a few insights from the session—and what I took away from the event overall.

Driving Value with Data + AI

Our goal was to help attendees answer three key questions:

  • Why SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks?
  • What value can this bring to my organization?
  • How do they work together in practice?

It’s no secret that data and AI are reshaping the future of business. Companies that can turn their data into actionable insights—quickly, securely, and at scale—are the ones that will lead in their industries. But too many are still held back by siloed data, inconsistent quality, and tools that don’t talk to each other.

The Trust Gap is Real

One of the most striking stats we shared was from a recent survey of 1,200 business and IT leaders: only 34% have high trust in their data capabilities. That’s a wake-up call. Organizations are investing heavily in data platforms, yet many still struggle with aligning IT and business needs or ensuring data is ready for AI-driven use cases.

What SAP and Databricks Are Doing Differently

What stood out most in our session was showing how SAP and Databricks are partnering to change that. This is more than just a technical integration—it’s a strategic shift.

With SAP Business Data Cloud, customers can:

  • Access live, trusted SAP data products without duplication
  • Preserve business semantics and lineage
  • ML/AI development in pro-code environment

SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud enables a zero-copy architecture that reduces time, effort, and risk when building production-grade AI solutions.

What Customers Told Me

One of my favorite parts of SAP Sapphire was speaking with customers one-on-one. Many were excited about how SAP-managed data products could drastically reduce the time and complexity of their data engineering tasks. The idea of getting "AI-ready" data out of SAP systems, without writing hundreds of custom pipelines, really resonated.

Several clients mentioned how this approach could help close the gap between IT and business teams, giving analysts and data scientists quicker access to meaningful, governed data. That’s a huge win for productivity and innovation.

My Takeaway

SAP Sapphire reminded me that we’re at a tipping point: data and AI are no longer "nice to have"—they’re critical to staying competitive. But what makes the difference isn’t just technology. It’s trust. Trust in the data. Trust in the platform. And trust that the tools will work together.

SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks are helping organizations make that leap.

Let’s Keep the Conversation Going

One of the best parts of the event? Meeting new people—partners, customers, colleagues—and hearing how you're tackling data and AI challenges in the real world. Let’s not stop here.

👉 Introduce yourself in the comments! I’d love to hear what you're working on and how you see data + AI evolving at your organization.

And if you're looking to go deeper, here are some helpful resources:

  • Try it out!
  • Business Data Cloud help documentation

Let’s keep learning from each other.

entry.title: Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products
entry.content:
In my earlier 2 blogs I have talked about overview of SAP BDC and its key features.

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

In this blog we will continue to deep dive in SAP BDC key feature Data Products.

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products

What are Data products in SAP BDC?

Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud serve as a standardized and efficient way to share and consume data across applications and domains. They enable analytic scenarios, AI applications, and facilitate data integration while being optimized for intensive reads. Managed with a product mindset, they are supported by high-quality metadata and governed by decentralized ownership principles.

Data Product is a grouping concept that carries the relevant metadata to describe the dataset and its data qualities. It may consists of multiple objects.

A data product is a self-contained set of tables that has data exposed for consumption outside the producing application or service via APIs.

SAP applications such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud produce data products that can be consumed in SAP Datasphere via SAP Business Data Cloud data packages. Data products are also included in and provide the data for consumption by SAP Business Data Cloud intelligent applications.

A Data Product itself is not directly consumable, but it exposes data through output ports, which can be implemented as APIs or events.

A data product provides a predefined and stable structure and also the inbound and outbound interfaces for source system extraction and end tool consumption.

Data products are created in and only available in SAP Datasphere.

Basically, a Data product acts like a Datasource that can, not-only pull data from your sources but also has the required structure to store it, load capabilities and can help consume this data across various intelligent applications.

When an Intelligent Application is installed, it often creates one or more Data Products by pulling in raw business data from source systems, transforming and organizing it during the setup process. During this process the data extraction, harmonization, and integration is taken care by Data products.

 

Key Objectives​

  1. Efficient Data Sharing Across Domains: Data Products facilitate replication-free integration and consumption by SAP, customer, and partner applications via APIs and Events.
  2. Efficient Data Storage: Data Products are processed and curated in a modern object-store based data lake architecture with highly scalable Spark processing.
  3. High-Quality Metadata: Metadata includes business semantics and is accessible through directories like the Data Product Directory and ORD Aggregators, enhancing discoverability.
  4. Optimized for Analytics: Data sets are curated for intensive reads and consumed in a read-only fashion, ensuring efficiency and reliability.
  5. Supporting Analytical and AI Applications: Data Products provide foundational data for dashboards, analytical models, and AI applications.
  6. Decentralized Ownership: Inspired by Data Mesh principles, Data Products are owned and managed by domain experts or teams responsible for operational data.
  7. Lifecycle Management: Data Products undergo needs analysis, design, and delivery phases, ensuring their accuracy and relevance.

Types

A data product can be of the type:

  • Primary: A data product exposed for consumption directly from an application. It's likely not to have input ports.
  • Derived: A data product that aggregates and combines data from multiple sources to provide value-added data sets. Derived data products must provide at least one input port with an integration dependency with at least one requirement.

Categories

Based on the dataset associated with the data product, it can have the following categories:

  • Business objects: The dataset contains business objects of type master data and transactional data.
  • Analytical data: The dataset contains analytical data such as KPIs, cubes, and metrics.
  • Other: All other types of datasets such as configuration data, mixed, and so on.

What are Data Product Definition files?

 Data Product Definition files are structured artifacts that describe and encapsulate curated datasets—either master or transactional data—designed for easy, secure, and reusable consumption across applications and domains. These files define the metadata, structure, and access interfaces of a data product.

These files are built using Open Resource Discovery (ORD) standards, ensuring consistency and interoperability.

Stored within Foundation Services, these definition files play a key role in discovering required data products.

As we continue our journey with SAP BDC we hope to discover more usage of Data products and how they can be utilized in the best way possible.

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in May
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in May

Another month with great new releases is in the books ✨
We delivered great new features in SAP Datasphere with all May releases. Learn more in my short top features video in May 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

My top features in May

 

Replication Flows

Reusing a Source Object in Several Replication Flows

You can now use a single source object in multiple replication flows. So far, the objects could only be used in one replication flow, but now this restriction was lifted and reusability is allowed. 
➡️  More information.

 

SFTP as Target for Replication Flow

You can now create replication flows to replicate data from supported source systems into Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) targets with load types ‘initial only’ and ‘initial and delta’ with parquet, JSON and CSV files. 
➡️  More information.

 

Array support for Confluent Kafka as Source

For Confluent Kafka sources you can now expand arrays or maps when reading from Confluent topics. In the replication flow editor you can change the schema properties of an individual object with primary keys and custom opcode columns and values. 
➡️   More information.

 

Task Scheduling with shorter Increments

The new enhanced scheduling feature allows tasks to be set at 5-minute intervals, offering greater flexibility and precision in task management. 
➡️   More information.

 

Local Table Partitioning With Hash Partitioning

When creating your local table from the Data Builder you can define partitions based on one or several columns of your table to break your data down into smaller and more manageable parts. You can now choose between range partitioning or hash partitioning. 
➡️   More information.

 

 

SAPPHIRE

May covered two exceptional SAP SAPPHIRE events in Orlando and Madrid. We had great coverage with more than 30 sessions on SAP Business Data Cloud including SAP Datasphere by product managers, executives, customers, and partners covering all areas of BDC including roadmap sessions, demos, and strategy talks. Some of them have been recorded and can be accessed via the 🔗 SAP Business Data Cloud track on the session catalog.

 

More blogs to check out 👇

  • Export Datasphere Views Data in CSV Format
  • Release Navigator for SAP BTP - What's New in Q2 2025

  • New Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey – From Data to Intelligence!
  • SAP Business Data CloudについてのFAQ

  • SAP Business Data Cloud – Central catalog feature revealed
  • Integrating Open SQL Schema Tables with SAP Datasphere Space using Dataflow

entry.title: Session 3 Recap & Highlights– Unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud for Enterprise Architects
entry.content:
I opened the session by highlighting the strategic intent of the webcast series. Having covered the high-level vision of data and AI in earlier episodes, this third instalment focused on unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud specifically for enterprise architects. We were joined by a strong lineup of speakers from CS&D, Product Management, and the Enterprise Architecture & Advisory teams — each bringing a unique perspective, from product strategy and architecture to real-world implementation and future roadmap.

@AmoghUmbarkar  opened the main content with a compelling message: data must move from being a burden to becoming a strategic enabler. He emphasized how BDC tackles key challenges in enterprise data landscapes — including fragmented integration efforts, siloed systems, and the growing need for faster, governed access to insights.

“Let’s not forget — data alone is not the answer. We need to embed it into the business process to guide all functions.”

He talked about concept of “Data as a Product,” moving away from traditional “Data as a Service” models. Amogh drew an analogy between the old ways of fetching water and today’s ready to consume bottled water to illustrate the shift toward curated, ready-to-consume, business-context-rich data products. These products empower users, enabling organizations to move from “gatekeepers to shopkeepers.”

Amogh also showcased how SAP itself acts as “Customer Zero,” demonstrating real use cases — including a 60-day implementation of a working capital intelligent app that achieved high business adoption and governance alignment.

@ralph_richter  provided a deep dive into the architecture of SAP’s Business Data Cloud. He explained how SAP leverages a layered, modular architecture built on:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for visualization and planning
  • SAP Data Sphere for governance, federation, and lineage
  • Databricks integration for AI/ML and data science
  • Zero-copy data sharing to minimize replication
  • Business Data Cockpit for orchestration and lifecycle management

Ralph also introduced SAP’s growing library of intelligent applications, starting with Working Capital Insights, that address key business questions around payment terms, DSO, and capital optimization.

 The technically rich portion of the session came from Axel Meier, who demystified the “Data Product” concept in SAP’s vision. Axel described data products as semantically enriched, business-contextualized, and metadata-driven datasets, available in a zero-copy, fully governed environment. These are built for reuse, integrated by design, and updated continuously.

        “Data products are not just one-to-one copies of CDS views. They come pre-integrated, enriched, and detached from source systems to enable scalable, cross-application reuse.”

Axel Meier also highlighted SAP’s collaboration with Databricks, showcasing how SAP uses Delta Lake and Delta Sharing protocols for seamless external consumption. He demonstrated live how financial planning data products appear in both SAP and Databricks environments, underlining the ease and power of cross-platform access.

What’s Next and How to Get Started

Ralph Richter concluded the session with an invitation to explore BDC through:

  • BDC Discovery Workshops – Offered in 2-hour, half-day, and full-day formats.

  • Free Landscape Assessments – Evaluating readiness and tailoring BDC journeys.

  • Service Offerings – From MaxAttention to implementation accelerators.

Session 3 of SAP’s Business Data Cloud series was a masterclass in how to shift from legacy data integration to future-ready, intelligent data ecosystems. The emphasis on business-aligned data products, seamless integration with hyperscalers, and intelligent applications provides a powerful framework for architects to rethink enterprise data strategies.

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below: https://go4.events.sap.com/shift-eaa-bdc-webinar/en_us/home.html

  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - Templates Best Practices
entry.content:
This article is part of a blog series on Dashboard Design BestPractices, created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.
Click here to open the Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series hub page in a new window. 

Blog Content

This blog illustrates where to find the template, a step-by-step description of how to customize it and a step-by-step explanation of how to create a logic group from scratch.

 

Where to find the Template?

Find all information about the template in this blog.
 
Here 's a sample story created with the template in just a few clicks.
In the next chapter, you will learn how to customize the template and quickly achieve your desired goal.

 

Template Customization

 Step-by Step description how to:
  1. Add Content to Placeholders 
  2. Remove Placeholders and delete Sections or Widgets 
  3. Adjust Page Content 

 

1. Add Content to Placeholders

Select the button in the placeholder and choose the model you want to use in the dialog that appears. 

 

Add desired measures and dimensions.

 

A specific chart type is predefined for each placeholder. 
However, this can be changed in the Builder Panel.

 

2. Remove Placeholders and delete Sections or Widgets 

To remove a placeholder, select the placeholder, select the three dots and
choose "Remove" from the context menu. Due to the underlying container structure,
the remaining content adapts automatically.

 

To delete an entire section within the template, you can also use the option to delete it from the outline. 
The layout automatically adjusts after deletion.

 

3. Add Page Content

There are various ways to add more content to the page.The easiest way is to copy and paste existing content and then adapt it. 

Step-by Step Example: Copy and Paste a Single Chart in a Logic Group

  • In the outline, select the panel with the chart that you want to copy

 

  • Use either the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + C” on Windows or “Command + C” on Mac, or the Copy function in the toolbar.
  • In the outline, select the section where you want to paste the content.

 

  • To paste, use either the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + V” on Windows or “Command + V” on Mac, or the Paste function in the toolbar.

After content has been added, you can adjust it in the builder or styling panel.

Example 2:

Step-by Step Example: Copy Existing Logic Group

  • Select the panel with the logic group that you want to copy, then use the copy functions as described in Example 1.

 

  • Select the section where you want to paste the logic group,
    then use the paste functions as described in Example 1.

 

 

The FlowLayoutPanel automatically positions the added Logic Group downwards.
Remember, while the contents of the individual sections, which are on one level, are arranged from top to bottom, the presentation in the outline is reversed. Therefore, what is at the top visually is at the bottom in the outline structure.

 

 

 

Build a Logic Group from Scratch

Step 1: Create New Story

  • Go to your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.
  • Select Canvas.

Step 2: Add a Panel to the Page

  • In the toolbar, select the add button > Containers > Panel.

  •  

    In the styling panel, adopt the values for Size and Position:
    Width = 100% I  Height = 400px I  Left = 0px I  Right = auto I  Top = 0px I  Bottom = auto

 

Step 3: Add Card Panel in Existing Panel

  • Add an additional panel to the first panel. 
  • To use the Fiori Horizon theme for the panel, enter “card” under CSS Class Name in the styling panel.

    Set the Size and Position:
    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = 16px I  Top = 16px I  Bottom = 8px

 

 

Step 4: Add Panel for Logic Group Header

  • Add an additional panel for the header text to the previous panel.
  • To get a visual separator, in the CSS Class Name field in the styling panel, add “logic-group__header”.
  • Set Size and Position: Width = auto I  Height = 48px I  Left = 0px I  Right = 0px I  Top = 0px I  
    Bottom = auto 
  • Set Corner Radius to 0px.

     

Step 5: Add Text Element to Header Panel

  • Choose Text and enter the name of your logic group.
  • To use the Fiori Horizon theme for the header text, in the CSS Class Name field in the styling panel,
    add “logic-group__title”.
  • Set Size and Position:
    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = individually I  Top = 10px I  Bottom = 0px
     
     

 

Step 6: Add Flow Layout Panel for Content

  • Select Panel_2
  • Choose Containers > Flow Layout Panel.

 

 

  • In the styling panel, set Size and Position for the Flow Layout Panel:

    Width = auto I  Height = auto I  Left = 16px I  Right = 16px I  Top = 58px I  Bottom = 8px

 

Step 7: Add Chart Widget

  • Insert a chart widget into the flow layout panel.

 

  • Select chart type and define the measures and dimensions.

 

  • In the styling panel, set Size and Position:

    Width = 50% I  Height = 100%

 

Step 8: Copy and paste chart widget

  • Select the chart that you want to copy.

  • Use the Copy function in the toolbar or use the
    keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + C” on Windows or “Command + C” on Mac.

 

  • Select the flow layout panel where you want to paste the chart to.

 

  • Use the Paste function in the toolbar or use the keyboard shortcuts “Ctrl + V” on Windows or “Command + V” on Mac.

 

  • Select chart type and define the measures and dimensions.

 

 

If you wanted to create a logic group with two chart widgets, this is the result.

 
To add more charts to the logic group, repeat the steps, but you may need to adjust the width of each chart as needed. For example, if you have three widgets side by side, use 33% for every chart widget.

 

Result

 Congratulations! Your logic group should now look something like this.

entry.title: Session 4 Recap & Highlights - Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization
entry.content:
Now let us look at what we covered in the session ‘Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization’.  In the rapidly evolving world of enterprise data analytics and AI, SAP customers are evaluating how they can transform their legacy SAP Business Warehouse (BW) systems to support real-time decision-making, artificial intelligence, and cloud agility? SAP BW modernization isn’t just a technical exercise—it’s a strategic initiative aimed at redefining how you extract maximum value from your data.

The goal is to shift from legacy data structures to a modern, cloud-native data platform that integrates artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and modern intuitive analytics. SAP Business Data Cloud, as the successor and evolution of SAP’s Business Data Fabric strategy, represents a fully managed SaaS offering. It centralizes access to SAP and non-SAP data, simplifies complex analytics workflows, and democratizes intelligence through SAP Joule Just Ask for natural language querying.

The Strategic Objective of BW Modernization

SAP BW systems have long served as the analytical backbone for many enterprises. But the world has changed. Business leaders today demand real-time insight, AI-powered recommendations, and integration across SAP and non-SAP ecosystems. Traditional BW systems, often rigid and batch-oriented, simply weren’t built for this new era.

Enter the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), SAP’s next-generation SaaS data platform. At its core, BDC is designed to unify SAP and third-party data, enable real-time analytics, and accelerate the deployment of AI/ML applications. It leverages the concept of “data products”—modular, context-aware building blocks of business data that can be easily consumed across systems, dashboards, or intelligent apps.

BW modernization is about shedding legacy complexity and stepping into a modern data operating model. The value proposition? Accelerated business agility, lower total cost of ownership, improved decision-making, and readiness for whatever comes next.

 Why does the Business Data Lakehouse Change the Game?

One of the most compelling aspects of SAP’s modernization vision is the shift to a business data lakehouse architecture—an approach that combines the best of traditional data warehouses (governance, quality, semantics) with the flexibility and scale of data lakes.

SAP’s partnership with Databricks plays a pivotal role here. Together, we’ve created a blueprint for integrating structured SAP data with unstructured or semi-structured third-party data. Through zero-copy integration with Databricks’ Delta Sharing protocol, BDC allows AI/ML models to run directly on operational data—no replication and no movement, no latency. With Business semantics being embedded into the data products themselves, they become context aware, eliminating the need for manual Excel-based definitions or reconciliation layers. And tools like SAP Joule let you query your data using natural language—bringing business users closer to data than ever before. This isn’t just an IT capability; it’s a fundamental reimagining of how organizations interact with data.

So, how to you I about modernizing you SAP BW Landscape?

Step One: Assess Your Current BW Landscape

Before plotting a course to BDC, you need a detailed understanding of your current BW environment. SAP offers a free, SAP BDC assessment that collects metadata (not business data) from your production system. The goal is to build a complete inventory of:

  • InfoProviders, DSOs, Composite Providers, and BW Queries
  • Source systems and integration points (ECC, flat files, third-party apps)
  • Usage statistics and performance metrics
  • Custom ABAP exits and transformations

This inventory reveals not only technical complexity but also opportunities for simplification and reuse. It is, in essence, your modernization blueprint. SAP provides a personalized report with recommendations and a proposed transformation path, tailored to your system’s architecture and business needs. You can request SAP BDC Assessment Today through this form: https://www.sap.com/registration/sap-bdc-modernization-assessment.html

 

Pathways to modernize your BW Landscape

BW modernization is not a monolithic project. SAP has identified pathways that cater to different business scenarios, maturity levels, and risk appetites. These four scenarios are:

  1. Embedded Scenario applicable for embedded BW customers and requires a conversion to a stand-alone SAP BW, Private Cloud Edition (PCE).
  2. Greenfield scenario for organizations ready to leave technical debt behind. It involves building a new data architecture in BDC using SAP and customer managed data products, SAP Datasphere semantic modeling and SAC dashboards. You’re not just replicating your BW logic—you’re rethinking it for agility, AI-readiness, and future innovation. This approach is particularly relevant for enterprises with heavily customized or aging BW systems that would be costly to refactor.
  3. Replatforming via BW Bridge: For those who want to preserve valuable BW investments while embracing the cloud, SAP Datasphere’s BW Bridge provides a middle ground. It allows the migration of BW models into Datasphere without needing to reimplement everything from scratch.
  4. Uplift to BW on Private Cloud Edition (PCE) offers a path to the cloud without changing the underlying BW models. You can then use the Data Product Generator to convert your BW assets to Data Products. The uplift enables integration with data products, Joule, and Databricks—all without touching your core BW logic.

 You can check out more technical details of the pathways to SAP BDC below:

 

Enterprise Architecture View: Looking Beyond the Tech

The technical details are only half the story. From an enterprise architect’s perspective, BW modernization must be viewed through multiple strategic lenses:

  • Architecture Viewpoint:  It defines how data will flow across systems, how security and lineage are maintained, and how capabilities are modularized into products. Mapping this future-state architecture ensures consistency, scalability, and integration.
  • Operational Viewpoint: A modern data architecture must run seamlessly. That means defining governance frameworks, security policies, and SLA-backed operations. It also includes monitoring lineage, managing metadata, and ensuring auditability across hybrid environments.
  • Strategic Viewpoint: Every transformation should tie back to business value. Modernization isn’t just about saving money or upgrading systems—it’s about enabling real-time decisions, predictive insights, and faster go-to-market strategies.
  • Stakeholder Viewpoint: Different stakeholders have different needs: business users want self-service, IT teams need manageability, and executives care about ROI. The architect’s job is to align these perspectives into a unified vision and execution plan.
  • Organizational Change Management: Perhaps the hardest part of modernization is change. Skill gaps, resistance to new tools, and silos between teams can derail even the best architectures. That’s why SAP now offers curated learning journeys, Discovery Center missions, and community support to help organizations build muscle around SAP BDC offering.

 If you’re ready to explore how the BW modernization journey could look like for you, SAP offers a complimentary BDC Discovery Workshop. It includes:

  • A deep dive into your current landscape
  • Introduction to BDC components and use cases
  • Reference architectures and migration options
  • Access to BDC experts

This workshop can be conducted remotely, hybrid, or on-site, depending on your needs – you can register for it now: https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/sap-migration-assessment.html or speak to your SAP Account team.

BW modernization is not just a technical imperative—it’s a strategic opportunity. With BDC, SAP is offering more than a platform; it’s delivering an ecosystem that blends business context, operational scale, and AI agility. Whether you choose to go greenfield, replatform, or uplift, the key is to start. As ECC customers move to S/4HANA, BW modernization should follow suit—not as an afterthought, but as a parallel pillar of enterprise innovation.

If you’re an architect, now is the time to engage. Align your data vision with business strategy. Evaluate your existing landscape. Map out your migration path. And above all, champion the organizational change that makes all of this stick. SAP BDC is the future,  Are you ready to build it? 

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below: https://go4.events.sap.com/shift-eaa-bdc-webinar/en_us/home.html

Important links:

  1. Architecture Center: https://architecture.learning.sap.com/
  2. Enterprise Architect Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-enterprise-architecture
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

@PaulKurchina @moshenaveh @ralph_richter @JaSoN_Luo @Timo  @Gaurish-Dessai 

SAP Business Data Cloud   SAP Datasphere   Data and Analytics   SAP Analytics Cloud   BW (SAP Business Warehouse)

entry.title: People Analytics – Reporting | A Real Consultant Story on Cleaning Duplicate Data
entry.content:
Working with ERP systems like SAP, Oracle, or Workday often comes with one universal pain—reporting.

The challenge isn’t just creating a report. That part is usually straightforward—drag and drop fields, define filters, and hit run. But what happens after that? You export the report to Excel… and the real work begins.

Suddenly you’re cleaning up duplicate rows, fixing totals, applying VLOOKUPs, and trying to present something trustworthy for leadership. We’ve all been there.

Recently, my colleague Nidhi and I faced exactly this while building a Compensation Report in SAP SuccessFactors People Analytics (Canvas Reporting). Our goal was clear: build something clean, accurate, and usable—without needing post-export manual work.

Here’s how we got there.

The Challenge – Duplicate Rows & Messy Output

- Multiple rows per employee
- Manual cleanup
- Leadership fatigue

This wasn’t just a technical nuisance—it was undermining trust in the output, and by extension, in the team creating it.

Our Step-by-Step Approach to Fix It

1. Plan Before You Click

We started by clearly defining what the report needed to deliver. For us, that meant:
- Base compensation details (like pay component and amount)
- Personal identifiers (like employee ID, first and last name)
- Relevant job or salary structure data

We intentionally avoided adding too many fields or overly complex joins.

2. Create the Report in Canvas

We used Canvas Reporting inside SAP SuccessFactors. This format gave us flexibility to:
- Pull from multiple domains
- Manage data relationships visually
- Use Design View to control logic and apply smart formatting

 

 

 

 

 

Click on Edit query

 

Then select new query so that you can build your query through (pivot table)

 

3. Build the Query Carefully

With the design structure in place, we built the query with extra care:
- Chose only the necessary fields
- Linked tables via unique identifiers like Employee ID
- Avoided one-to-many or many-to-many joins

 

Note: Choose the right base object as instructed by the client requirement, expected to select the highest base object, as an instance where we choose “Compensation” instead of salary information similar if you are creating report for Time account balance you can choose “Time account” and it is Leave transaction report choose “Employee time” and so on.

 

 

Click on Save and then Return.

 

You will be dragged to the below screen, click Show Design View.

 

In SAP SuccessFactors reports, measures represent quantifiable data that is aggregated or analyzed, while dimensions provide the context or categories for the measures

 

 

4. Clean Up Duplicates with Pivot Logic

Inside Design View, we used Pivot Functions to eliminate unwanted duplicates:
- Grouped records and showed only the first instance of each pay component
- Applied logic to exclude blank or null values
- Used display rules for one row per employee

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

5. Review, Test, and Refine

Once built, we tested the report thoroughly:
- Ran live samples to spot inconsistencies
- Shared it with colleagues for review
- Adjusted logic to ensure accuracy and trust

 

 

 

What We Learned

Sometimes, the small operational problems—like duplicate rows in a report—can have a bigger business impact than the complex projects we work on.

Thanks to Nidhi for her collaboration, patience, and meticulousness throughout the process. This was a simple challenge, but solving it meant we could finally offer something useful to leadership—without requiring another manual step.

Why This Matters (Beyond SAP)

Whether you’re using SAP, Oracle OTBI, or Workday—this story will probably feel familiar.

You want reports that:
- Are clean and easy to read
- Don’t require manual work after download
- Can be trusted immediately by decision-makers

We’re sharing our experience to help others avoid the same struggle.

Final Thoughts

ERP tools are powerful—but clean reporting takes care, collaboration, and intent.

If you’re a fellow consultant, report builder, or HR tech practitioner: keep solving the small things. Sometimes, they’re what matter the most.

Let’s keep learning—and building—together.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction – July 2025 update
entry.content:
The SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction provides guidance to our SAP BusinessObjects customers on the product directions for SAP analytics solutions. We published a new version this month with some important updates which can be found here.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud delivers deep integration of Data Management, Analytics and Planning augmented by AI in one native cloud solution. This allows to move from insight to action, brings analytics closer to the point of decision and provides trusted insights from customers’ most valuable data.

SAP Analytics Cloud, as a key component of SAP Business Data Cloud, provides trustworthy analytics for any user from any context and remains the recommended option for all new planning and analytics projects. The closed loop from insight to action allows customers to identify challenges, analyze options and execute decisions from one place.

Our knowledge of customer data and integration to business process enable customers to rapidly deploy analytics to address their most important business problems.

 

SAP BusinessObjects BI

With more than 30 years of innovations, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence platform (SAP BusinessObjects BI) equips thousands of companies which reliably manage enterprise reporting use cases at scale. Our revised maintenance strategy guarantees Mainstream Maintenance until at least end of 2031 which secures your investments on the long run, whether you want to deploy on premise or in a private cloud.

New maintenance strategy

Starting with BI 4.3, Mainstream Maintenance is now followed by Customer Specific Maintenance during which we deliver fixes for high and very high security issues (CVSS >= 7) during the first year. We are extending BI 4.3 Mainstream Maintenance until end of 2026 so that security fixes are guaranteed until end of 2027 as previously committed.

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we adopt a revised delivery cycle which addresses the need for more stability while keeping regular updates: we are moving away from support packages delivered every year and supported only during 18 months to minor releases delivered every 2 years, benefiting from 3 years of Mainstream Maintenance, followed Customer Specific Maintenance including 1 year of security fixes.

We already plan for a next release, BI 2027, which should be available in Q1 2027, followed by another one 2 years later, and we will revisit our roadmap on a regular basis.

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 and beyond

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 is available since March 2025. This new version illustrates our strategy going forward: continue the modernization started in version 4.3 and streamline the suite by focusing on the core components while providing alternatives for unsupported ones.

Our strategy is based on 3 pillars: reach more business users, increase power users’ productivity and reduce total cost of ownership. To maximize the value for our customers, we will focus ongoing investments on the most-widely adopted SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions: SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, single source .unx universes, SAP Crystal Reports, and the SAP BusinessObjects BI platform.

 SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office and SAP Lumira Designer will be maintained and supported, but no new feature will be delivered.

We will provide alternatives

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we do not deliver anymore SAP Lumira Discovery, SAP Crystal Reports for Enterprise, SAP BusinessObjects Universe Design Tool and .unv universes, multi-source universes and associated connectivity, SAP BusinessObjects Analysis edition for OLAP, SAP BusinessObjects Live Office and SAP BusinessObjects Mobile, but we are recommending alternatives for all use cases.

We will stop supporting AIX and Solaris after version 4.3 and will focus on Windows and Linux.

 

Move your analytics to the cloud

For companies willing to move analytics workloads to the cloud, we offer 2 complementary options: SAP BusinessObjects BI operated in a private cloud and SAP Business Data Cloud.

SAP BusinessObjects, private cloud edition is an opportunity to shift from a maintenance contract to a subscription model while leveraging your existing investments in SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud is recommended for new applications, use cases and users, and along with our partner community, we are committed to support every customer through this journey with tools and programs.

 

Want to learn more?

Enjoy right now the full SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction.

entry.title: A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
entry.content:
Many developers have contacted me in message box asking how to start with learning SAP BDC.

SAP Has provided many learning paths for same which are available on the Learning hub, but, what about people who don’t have access to learning hub or someone who is still working in legacy technologies.

Sharing these learning links hoping that this will help atleast a few people who trying to learn SAP BDC.

 

Core Components of SAP BDC system

Layer

Description

Source Systems

Includes SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and external systems. Data is bundled into entities like tables and views for replication.

Foundation Services

Harmonizes and transforms raw data into Data Products. These are stored in a hyperscaler environment (SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake files).

SAP Datasphere

Acts as the semantic layer. Defines data models, manages access control, and supports both prebuilt and custom analytical scenarios.

SAP Databricks

Embedded AI/ML engine for advanced analytics. Enables pro-code engineering and machine learning extensions.

SAP Analytics Cloud

Provides visualization, planning, and ad-hoc analysis capabilities. Powers dashboards and intelligent applications.

BDC Cockpit

Central hub for managing Data Products, Intelligent Applications, and data sharing workflows.

 

You must learn SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics cloud to be ready for SAP BDC.

 

You may use below link to learn more about SAP Datasphere.

Get Started with Your Trial in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials

This mission is the ideal starting point for newcomers to start using SAP Datasphere, get their trial account, and learn the fundamentals for modelling their data in SAP Datasphere.

This training will cover below activities.

  1. Get to Know the SAP Datasphere Interface | SAP Tutorials : talks about how to navigate the user interface of SAP Datasphere and what the home screen controls can do for you
  2. Add Users and Assign Roles in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to add users into your SAP Datasphere tenant, how to assign roles to users, How to edit users in bulk
  3. Create and Monitor a Space in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to create a Space and how to manage and monitor your Space
  4. Create an Entity Relationship Model in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about overview of E/R Models, how to create an E/R Model, how to associate data columns and how to finalise an E/R Model and deploy
  5. Create a Graphical View in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : talks about graphical views, how to create them, how to rename and restore columns in Graphical view and their deployment
  6. Define Measures and Add Business Information to a View | SAP Tutorials talks about what is semantic information, how to define measures, how to add business information, how to change business names of measures and attributes, how to change the semantic type of measures and attributes and how to preview your modelled dataset
  7. Generate Time Table and Dimensions | SAP Tutorials talks about how to create time tables and dimensions and how to associate the time dimensions with your data
  8. Upload Flat Files and Wrangle Your Data | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to upload flat files in the Data Builder of SAP Datasphere, how to make the best of the Data Builder capabilities during a file upload process and how to transform the data for data consistency and integrity
  9. Replicate Data into SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to check the type of data access, how to create a real time data replication and how to schedule the data replication
  10. Integrate and Monitor Data with SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to access the Data Integration Monitor, how to use the Data Integration Monitor dashboard and the types of monitoring you can do with the Data Integration Monitor

 

 

You can use below links to know more about SAP Analytics cloud.

  1. Exploring SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Create a Live Data Connection in SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials
  3. Create Live Data Model and a Story | SAP Tutorials
  4. Develop and Consume Queries on SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials

SAP has basic trial versions for both SAP Datasphere and SAC where you may get some hands on knowledge to perform few activities.

Get started with Basic Trial | SAP Tutorials

 

Once you have a good understanding of SAP Datasphere and SAC, you can start going through SAP BDC learning paths.

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

 

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in June
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in June

Another month with a great new release delivery ✨
Learn more in my short top features video in June 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in June

 

SQL and Script Views as Source Objects for Your Replication Flows

You can create a replication flow with an SQL view or a script view as a source. Supported connections are SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA On-premise and SAP Datasphere. Initial only loads are currently supported, and you must define a primary key for your view to allow the deployment. 
➡️   More information

 

Python Version 3.11 available for Data Flows

The Data Flow script operator enables the Python version 3.11 for your data flows. When creating a data flow or modifying an existing one, you can now choose the new Python Version 3.11. Please note that Python 3.9 will reach its end-of-life soon, hence we recommend upgrading your data flows to 3.11 as the maintenance for 3.9 ends in October 2025. 
➡️   More information

 

New Data Types Supported for Local Tables (File)

We now support additional data types for local tables in the file space on the object store. You can now select the additional data types: DateTime, hana.BINARY and hana.TINYINT. 
➡️   More information

 

Object Store API calls

We separated API request calls from the compute in the flexible tenant configuration. That means you can now specify the number of API requests separately when configuring object storage. With the new option, you can define the expected number of API calls per month, giving you more control and accuracy in estimating your object storage needs. 
➡️   More information

 

 

My favorite blog in June

There is an excellent blog I want you to be aware of. My friend and co-author of multiple books @FrankRiesner wrote this blog about SAP BW PCE and explains what it is, and also what it is not.
