entry.title: Automating Flat File Loads in SAP Datasphere Using Generic SFTP Connections
entry.content:
With Datasphere release 2025.11, SAP introduced a powerful new feature: the Generic SFTP Connection. This enhancement significantly simplifies and automates the process of loading flat files into Datasphere.
Traditionally, users had to manually upload each flat file, which was cumbersome especially when dealing with multiple files. Now, with Generic SFTP, the process can be fully automated using scripting (e.g., Python), resulting in faster and more efficient bulk data ingestion.

This blog walks you through a basic method to leverage the Generic SFTP connection as a source object in a Data Flow. File formats currently supported include:JSON, JSONL, CSV, XLS, XLSX, ORC, and PARQUET.

Key Benefits

  • Automates repetitive flat file loads
  • Supports bulk data ingestion
  • Can be orchestrated using SAP Integration Suite or custom scripts (e.g., Python)

Prerequisites

  1. Valid Generic SFTP Connection
  2. Source File Availability

Steps to Load Data from Generic SFTP

First, you need to create a Data Flow to handle how the data will be ingested when transferred to generic SFTP

  • Go to the "Sources" tab in the Data Builder. Expand the "Connections" folder, navigate to the SFTP connection, and select the folder containing the source file.

 

  • Drag and drop the file onto the canvas.
  • (Optional) Click "Modify" to edit columns if needed. You can rename, remove, or change data types.

  • Click the source node and choose "Add Table" to create a new target table.
  • Click "Create and Deploy Table".
  • Choose the appropriate load Mode:
    • Append – Add new records to existing data
    • Truncate – Clear existing data before loading
    • Delete – Remove existing records based on matching keys before loading
  • Run the Data Flow to load data into the target table.

Example Use Case: Automating Product Image Integration

Our organization leveraged the Generic SFTP Connections feature in SAP Datasphere to automate the integration of product image data into Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Here's how the solution was implemented:

  • A third-party system generates a flat file containing Product IDs and corresponding image URLs every time a new product is added.
  • For the initial load, we used a Python script to transfer this file to the SFTP server. A Dataflow configured in Append mode then loaded the file into a target table in Datasphere.
  • To incorporate the image URLs into the data model, we extended the Product Master Data dimension in Datasphere by adding a new attribute for the image URL. The semantic type of this attribute was set to "Image URL".
  • This enhancement allowed seamless integration into existing SAC dashboards, enabling dynamic display of product images.
  • For ongoing daily updates, we scheduled the Dataflow to run automatically. SAP Integration Suite transfers the updated file to the same SFTP folder each day, using a consistent file name to support full automation.

End result

# Generic script to transfer file to SFTP Server
# Be sure to change the source file and destination folder name
import paramiko
import os
# === SFTP connection details ===
hostname = <enter SFTP host> 
port = 22  # Usually 22 for SFTP
username = <enter user name> 
password = <Enter password> 
# === Local file and remote folder ===
local_file_path = < Source File name with Path> 
remote_folder_path = <Target Destination>    # No filename, just the folder

def upload_file_sftp():
   try:
       # Extract just the filename
       filename = os.path.basename(local_file_path)
       remote_file_path = os.path.join(remote_folder_path, filename).replace('\\', '/')

       # Connect to SFTP
       transport = paramiko.Transport((hostname, port))
       transport.banner_timeout = 10  # Prevent timeout errors
       transport.connect(username=username, password=password)

       sftp = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)

       # Upload the file
       print(f"Uploading {local_file_path} to {remote_file_path}")
       sftp.put(local_file_path, remote_file_path)
       print("Upload successful.")
       sftp.close()
   transport.close()

   except Exception as e:
       print(f"Error occurred: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
   upload_file_sftp()

Conclusion

This new feature drastically streamlined data ingestion pipelines and reduced manual effort for teams managing frequent flat file loads. By combining Datasphere’s Generic SFTP connections with automation scripts, organizations can achieve fully managed and scalable data pipelines

entry.title: SAP BDC Ecosystem
entry.content:
By now you may have got a good understanding of SAP BDC components from my earlier blogs.

Now let's try to see how it all fits together.

 

 

At the first level we start with the data repository source. It may be an SAP system (like SAP S/4, Success Factor, SAP BW etc. )  or any non-SAP system.

Customers struggle a lot in heterogeneous system where data is stored in multiple different data storage systems. This data is vital for reporting.

 

For the data-driven modern organisations, having convenient access to all the necessary data in a specific and centralised location is important. Easy, convenient access ensures that data resources are always available at a moment’s notice, easing the process for you and allowing you to conduct all operations. 

 

With SAP BDC, various in-built SAP provided connectors available which we can use to connect to SAP as well as non-SAP systems and integrate them as a source of information i.e. transactional & master data.

SAP BDC system resides in SAP BTP platform similar to SAP Datasphere tenant sub-accounts currently. 

You will have a separate SAP Datasphere instance inside your SAP BDC environment.

SAP Datasphere is the evolution of the SAP data warehouse(earlier SAP BW) solution in the cloud, combining capabilities from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud with its agile enterprise data warehouse, self-service data modelling and SAP Data Intelligence Cloud with its data orchestration, lineage, quality, among other capabilities.

In data integration projects, a lot of time is spent trying to recreate context that has been lost during data replication, especially when getting data from the database layer belonging to heterogeneous storage systems.

With SAP BDC, customers will be able to bring all the structured and non-structured data under single umbrella in business data fabric.

This simplifies complex data landscapes and delivers meaningful data to every data consumer, be it Data architect, business user or a decision maker – it takes the benefits and value further by keeping the business logic and application context from data intact.

For each of the source systems, SAP has provided ready-to-use data products which can be found in SAP BDC Cockpit.

To use out-of-the-box Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud with third-party data, first browse the available Data Products in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Then select and install the one that best meets your requirements before proceeding with integration.

 

 

 

 SAP BDC system eliminates the need to recreate all the business context lost from extracting data - giving business stakeholders and data consumers the ability to accelerate their decision-making with trust and confidence, knowing they always have the complete picture of their data regardless of where it is stored or how it was designed.

 

SAP Data products are combination of curated views & tables, metadata, access control, inbound and outbound interfaces, load capabilities, data lineage etc. which are used by semantic layer in SAP Datasphere by consumption ready data models which can be then used for internal data manipulation and transformation.

 

This data can then be used for

  1. Reporting by SAP Analytics cloud through live data, dashboards and stories
  2. AI/ML capabilities by Databricks for powerful compute and advance analytics
  3. Visualization by intelligent apps for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively

 

SAP BDC replicates source data into Datasphere object store once; downstream consumers access it from there.

With use of delta Sharing , Databricks gets real-time access to data without duplication saving storage space and associated costs.

 

 

 

All in all, SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality.

  • SAP BDC combines SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and their capabilities into one fully managed SaaS solution for all data and analytics needs.
  • It seamlessly integrates mission-critical SAP data with third-party sources—without losing business context or requiring constant extraction.
  • SAP transforms and harmonizes business data within a hyperscaler environment, ensuring high-quality, ready-to-use data across the board.
  • Prebuilt SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications deliver instant, AI-powered business insights with minimal setup, accelerating decision-making and innovation.

 

Ultimately, SAP BDC helps organizations:

  • Streamline operations with advanced data pipelines
  • Accelerate innovation through AI and predictive analytics
  • Improve agility by enabling teams to respond to change quickly
  • Drive business growth by turning data into a competitive advantage

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

entry.title: Data Lineage – Do it Yourself with SAP HANA and SAC
entry.content:
Management Summary 

  1. Data lineage is crucial for understanding the origin and usage of data – a central requirement for data governance, data quality, and efficient data management. 
  2. With SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a cost-effective and quickly implementable solution for data lineage can be realized, as both products are already included in the licensing of many companies. 
  3. The Object Dependencies in SAP HANA provide comprehensive information about dependencies between tables, views, and other objects, which can be directly read in SAC via a live connection. 
  4. Thanks to the R-integration in SAC (e.g., with the R package "collapsibleTree"), an interactive tree representation is created, offering business users an intuitive and transparent overview of data flows and relationships. 
  5. This approach enables an automated, real-time view of data origin, improves the maintainability of reports and data models, and lays the foundation for reliable and data governance-compliant analytics applications.

Introduction

In modern data warehouse architectures, data lineage plays an increasingly important role. Companies want to trace where data comes from, how it is transformed, and in which reports it is ultimately used. Transparent data origin significantly contributes to data quality and governance. It also creates data understanding and facilitates the implementation of reporting requirements, especially in self-service environments.

Companies with an SAP tech stack are often familiar with the principle of data lineage from SAP BW, where data flows can be visualized via the data flow object. However, in modern system landscapes where SAP BW is combined with SAP HANA – for example, through hybrid architectures with native HANA views and BW objects – this visualization reaches its limits. In native HANA development, such visualization options are even completely missing.

Although established tools like Collibra or D-QUANTUM offer comprehensive lineage functions, they require additional licenses, implementation effort and a structuring of organizational process to get the full potential out of the tools. For many use cases – such as error analysis or the development of new requirements – a lighter solution is sufficient.

Therefore, we looked for a lean and quickly implementable alternative that supports development in complex system landscapes. Our goal: to automatically identify and visualize the dependencies of SAP HANA objects – without additional third-party tools.

In this blog post, we show how to implement a cost-effective and quick visualization of data lineage using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and a live connection to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). A special highlight: Through the integration of R in SAC (including the R package "collapsibleTree"), data origin is visualized in an interactive tree structure in an SAC story.

 

Motivation: Why Data Lineage?

The requirements for transparency, traceability, and efficiency in data architectures are increasing – especially in regulated and data-driven companies. Data lineage makes a decisive contribution here:

  • Transparency: Knowing the origin and usage of data creates trust and better decision-making foundations.
  • Data understanding: A clear overview of data flows facilitates both operation and the implementation of reporting and analysis requirements.
  • Maintainability: Changes in the data model can be better assessed if the affected downstream objects are known.
  • Compliance: Regulations like GDPR require traceable documentation of data processing.

Many companies already have some form of data lineage – but usually maintained manually by data engineers in PowerPoint, Excel, or Word. The result: high maintenance effort, outdated documentation, and lack of up-to-date information in ongoing operations.

Our solution is based on existing SAP HANA and SAC licenses and combines automated determination of data flows with an interactive representation through R integration. This creates a maintainable, always up-to-date, and interactive overview of data flows – without additional tools or costs.

 

Technical Background: SAP HANA Object Dependencies

SAP HANA provides Object Dependencies in the form of metadata tables and views, where relationships between different objects are stored. Here you can find information about which objects depend on and are linked to each other. A brief overview:

  • Data source: The Objects Dependencies View can be found in the HANA schema SYS under the name OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.
  • Object types: Tables, views, stored procedures, etc.
  • Dependencies: Relationships between objects, e.g., which tables or views are used for an SAC report.
  • Usage: Supports impact and lineage analyses directly at the database level.

Through a live connection in SAP Analytics Cloud, this information can be queried and visualized in real-time.

Figure 1: Extract from the Object Dependencies | SELECT TOP 1000 * FROM SYS.OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.

Implementation in SAP Analytics Cloud

To implement the data lineage solution in SAC, two prerequisites must be met:

  • Live connection to SAP HANA: With the HANA live connection the necessary metadata is read from HANA in real time to ensure that it is up to date. This live connection must be created.
  • R server configuration: An R package is used for visualization. The use of R must be activated in SAC.

The necessary steps in order to create the lineage visualization can be summarized as follows:

  • Data preparation in SAP HANA
    • Preparation of metadata: For optimal visualization, the metadata is prepared, e.g., filtering object types, enriching descriptions.
    • Provision as a calculation view: The data is prepared as a calculation view as a basis for the SAC story.
  • Establishing a live connection to HANA
    • Configure live connection: Set up the HANA connection in SAC under Connections → Live Data Connection.
    • Create data model in SAC: Reference the live data model to the created view/table.
  • Activate R integration in SAC
    • Configure R server: Specify the R server in SAC administration under System Configuration (either own server or the environment provided by SAP).
    • Create R scripts: In a story or an analytic application, the R package "collapsibleTree" can be loaded using the R widget function.
  • Create data lineage visualization with "collapsibleTree"
    • Pass data to R: Load the HANA table or view data into an R-compatible table structure via the R script in SAC.
    • Generate tree structure: Create an interactive tree representation with collapsibleTree::collapsibleTree(...) or a similar function.
    • Embed result: The generated graphic appears directly in the SAC story within the R widget and can be filtered and extended as needed.

Results and Benefits

  • Quick & cost-effective implementation: In this case, the customer already had SAP HANA and SAC licensed, so no additional investments were necessary.
  • Automation: Dependencies are read directly from SAP HANA Object Dependencies, eliminating the need for a separate ETL process or manual maintenance.
  • Interactive representation: Users can click through the tree structure and trace relationships between objects.

Figure 2: Representation of the data lineage within a SAC story.

Best Practices & Tips

  • Performance: For very large data volumes, it is advisable to perform aggregation or filtering in HANA beforehand and persist it.
  • Naming conventions: Consistent naming for tables and views makes the tree diagram easier to read.
  • Limitations: Complex procedures or dynamic SQL are not always fully recognized – additional manual mapping may be necessary.
  • Visualization in R: For data lineage representation, we use the R package collapsibleTree, which is included in the SAP-provided R runtime environment (packages in the SAP R server environment). It can be used directly and free of charge in SAC without additional infrastructure. For extended visualization options, an own R server with additional packages can alternatively be connected.

 

Conclusion and Outlook

The visualization of data lineage in SAP Analytics Cloud using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and the R package "collapsibleTree" is a lean and cost-effective solution for companies that want to make their data origin traceable.

Thanks to the live data connection between HANA and SAC, no complicated interfaces or additional licenses are needed. With the out-of-the-box R integration and the interactive widgets of SAC, the origin and usage of tables can be traced in detail with just a few clicks.

The presented solution offers an efficient way, minimum in the short term, to provide developers and business units with more transparency about data flows. In the medium to long term, the use of specialized data governance solutions like Collibra or D-Quantum is recommended to centrally manage lineage, documentation, and responsibilities.

 

Questions, Feedback, and Contact

We are happy to answer questions and engage in further discussions – either in the comments or through direct contact.

Do you need more information?

  • If further technical information is desired (e.g., configuration of the R server, scripting in SAC, performance optimization, manual mapping), let us know!
  • We are happy to dive deeper into the implementation details in a personal conversation.

We look forward to the exchange and are happy to provide further advice and implementation in the area of SAP Data & Analytics.

Authors:

Oliver Bulla (@OliverBulla), Senior Data Intelligence Consultant, specializing in SAP solutions, oliver.bulla@wavestone.com  

Christian Bantle (@christianbantle), Senior Data Intelligence Consultant, specializing in SAP solutions, christian.bantle@wavestone.com

(Disclaimer: This blog post is based on personal experiences and projects. The screenshots and examples shown are exemplary and may vary depending on the system landscape.)

entry.title: What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC3 2025 Release
entry.content:
Purpose

Hello SAP Community Colleagues,

In QRC3 2025, we have an action-packed list of new features that have now been made available in the modeling area of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud!

Overview

Learn more about these new features here:

  1. A new formula called WAVG (Weighted Average)

  2. First, Last and Average including unbooked data exception aggregation.

  3. Data Export API – Delta Aggregation.

 

  1. New formula - WAVG  (Weighted Average)

A new formula has been introduced into the modeler, called WAVG.  This formula calculates the weighted average of a member, based on the value of the corresponding members assigned weight.  It can be used in standard and account models.

How Weighted Average is calculated:

 

Dimension 

Price

Stock

Price * Stock

Bread

2

10

20

Bread

3

20

60

Bread

4

30

120

Total

8

60

200

Table 1: Table containing product, price and stock values

 

Table 1 shows a simple list of products with various prices and stock amounts.

To calculate the Average Price, use the following calculation:

(2+3+4)/3 = 3

To calculate the Weighted Average Price, use the following calculation: (2*10) + (3*20) + (4*30) / (10 + 20 + 30 ) = 200 / 60 = 3.33

The weighted average calculation can provide a more accurate result, based on the given weight, compared to an average calculation.

Syntax:

WAVG([Measure] or [Account Member], [Assigned Weight], [Dimension 1], [Dimension 2]... [Dimension 10])

For example:

Figure 1: Sample WAVG Syntax

The above WAVG formula calculates the weighted average of [Price] using [Volume] as the assigned weight, for a given Date and Product.

Up to 10 dimensions can be used within the WAVG formula.

Note that input enablement on cells containing this calculated measure is available on leaf members only, which is the lowest level of the hierarchy.  It is planned to make input enablement available on other members in the future.

2.  First, Last and Average Exception Aggregation including Unbooked Data

You can now compute first, last and average exception aggregation including unbooked data using a single dimension on a base measure or base account with these three new exception aggregation values:

  • Average incl. Unbooked calculates the average of all aggregated values, including unbooked values.
  • First incl. Unbooked shows the first (oldest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
  • Last incl. Unbooked shows the last (most recent) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.

Figure 2: New exception aggregations in modeler

These new exception aggregations are supported in the standard and account model and can help to provide more accurate results on aggregated data.

Average including unbooked exception aggregation example:

Figure 3: Illustration on how Average incl. Unbooked now considers all months in period, instead of just months containing booked values

In the above example, an Average incl. Unbooked exception aggregation is applied to a base measure.  The total in Q1 is 100, in Q2 is 200, in Q3 is 300 and in Q4 is 400.

When booked values are only considered, the average is the sum of these values, divided by the number of booked entries, i.e. (100+200+300+400)/4 months=250.

When considering unbooked data, a more accurate average exception aggregation can now be calculated. 

i.e. (100+200+300+400)/12 months = 83.33

First including unbooked exception aggregation example:

Figure 4: Illustration on how First incl. Unbooked now considers all months in period, instead of just months containing booked values

Figure 4 shows an example of how First Incl. Unbooked exception aggregation now considers unbooked values in the first period, compared to when using First exception aggregation, that defaults to booked values.  Should this example show an entry for February, the top level of the hierarchy will still show unbooked values, as January is now considered within the formula even though it contains no data.  This provides a more accurate First exception aggregation result of entries for a given period. 

Figure 5: Illustration on how Last incl. Unbooked now considers unbooked values for a given period

Figure 5 shows how Last incl. Unbooked exception aggregation compares to Last exception aggregation.  Last exception aggregation contains 400 for October.  As this is the last period that contains booked values, results are seen at the top level of the hierarchy.  In contrast, Last incl. Unbooked also contains 400 for October, however, the last period is December, which contains an unbooked value.  This unbooked value is therefore seen at the top level of the hierarchy for that period, providing a more accurate result for the Last aggregation.

3.  Data Export API – Fact Data Delta Aggregation

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of aggregated delta of fact data, using a new ‘FactDataAggregation‘ endpoint. 

This means that changed fact data can now be aggregated and then exported, compared to exporting all changed fact data.  This feature compliments how S/4 consumes aggregated fact data.

Modelers can also access this feature within the API Subcriptions tab in their model.

Figure 6: Fact Data Delta Aggregation entity set within the Create Subscriptions area of the model

An example of how Delta Aggregation works:

Account

Product

Sales

Account1

Water

100

Account1

Juice

150

Account2

Water

200

Account2

Juice

150

Table 2: Accounts 1 & 2 contains Products and Sales.

Table 2 shows Account1 & Account2 contains 2 products at various sales values.

Account

Sales

Account1

250

Account2

350

Table 3: Aggregated values of Account1 & Account2

Let’s modify the sales values for both accounts:

Account

Product

Sales

Account1

Water

110

Account1

Juice

80

Account2

Water

75

Table 4: Sales values have changed, reflecting changed fact data.

The sales value for Water in Account1 has been change from 100 to 110.

The sales value for Juice in Account1 has been change from 150 to 80.

The sales value for Water in Account2 has been change from 200 to 75.

There is no change for Juice in Account2.

The aggregated fact data values are therefore calculated as follows:

Account

Sales

Account1

((110 - 100) + (80 - 150)) = -60

Account2

((75-200) + (150 – 150)) = -125

Table 5: How the aggregated values are calculated

These are the values that will be exported using the ‘FactDataAggregation‘ endpoint or by using the Fact Data Delta Aggregation entity set in the API Subscriptions section of the model.

Conclusion

In summary, the following new features and updates have been introduced to the Modeling Extensions and Integration areas of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud, as part of QRC3 2025 release.

  1. A new formula, called WAVG, calculates the weighted average of a member, based on the value of the corresponding members assigned weight. 
  2. Three new exception aggregations can be applied to base measures and base accounts. 
    • First incl. Unbooked shows the first (oldest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
    • Last incl. Unbooked shows the last (newest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
    • Average incl. Unbooked calculates the average of all aggregated values, including unbooked values.
  3. The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of aggregated delta of fact data using a new ‘FactDataAggregation‘ endpoint.  Modelers can also use the new Fata Data Delta Aggregation entity set name in the API Subscriptions tab of the model.

If you have any questions, feel free to comment below or post a question to our SAP Analytics Cloud Questions & Answers forum.

See this SAP Knowledge Base Article if you’d like to learn more about FastTrack and Quarterly Release Cycle releases.

For further information, visit our SAP Analytics Cloud Community pages to find more product information, best practices, and more. 

To find out more about QRC release dates, see SAP Analytics Cloud tenants on Quarterly Release Cycle (QRC) updates in 2025.

Check out our SAP Road Map Explorer to see more upcoming features of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Thanks for reading!

entry.title: Marla Alschweiki
entry.content:
Marla

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Marla on LinkedIn

In Marla's own words: "I am a curious SAP Data Analytics & AI Developer with a strong focus on Business Intelligence, Embedded Analytics, and AI-driven development. Over the past eight years, I've worked across the SAP ecosystem from S/4HANA and SAP BW to SAP Analytics Cloud and Fiori/UI5, where I've helped design and implement clean, scalable solutions that bridge backend data architecture with user-friendly interfaces.

I specialize in building modular Virtual Data Models using CDS Views, aligned with SAP’s clean core strategy.

I'm especially excited about the evolving landscape of SAP Business AI and its potential to transform how enterprises operate from predictive analytics and intelligent process automation to personalized user experiences.

I'm a strong believer in continuous learning, open knowledge-sharing, and the power of community. Whether through mentorship, collaboration, blogs, or workshops, I actively seek out opportunities to grow, uplift others, and create spaces where everyone feels empowered to learn, contribute, and thrive."

Topics of interest: SAP Data Analytics, SAP Business AI, Embedded Analytics, SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Fiori/UI5

Marla, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Becoming a mentor is my way of giving back to the SAP community that’s played such a big role in my journey. I truly believe that knowledge grows when it’s shared, and I want to help others find clarity and confidence in this fast-moving field. With my background in product development, I can help approach problems with a critical eye and a practical mindset to build SAP solutions that truly address real-world needs and push innovation forward.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Stay curious and don’t be afraid to ask questions, no matter how simple they seem. SAP is a vast ecosystem, and nobody knows everything. Collaboration and continuous learning are key. Also, share your experiences! Whether it’s a small tip, a lesson learned, or a project success, your voice might be exactly what someone else needs to hear.

entry.title: Sneak Peek in to SAP Analytics Cloud release for Q3 2025
entry.content:
We have a very special AI focused release coming your way this quarter. In this blog we give you a sneak peek into our Top 5 features in SAP Analytics Cloud for QRC3 2025. A full list of what is coming can be found on our Roadmap Explorer.  Let's dive in!

AI-assisted advanced formula generation

This quarter we bring you a number of exciting new AI-assisted features and we will start by looking at AI-assisted advanced formula generation. Within the advanced formula editor this feature utilizes generative AI to create advanced formula script logic from natural language comments, making the process of developing data actions easier, quicker, and more efficient.

This feature can also generate descriptions of existing advanced formulas generated automatically in natural language, reducing time and complexity associated with creating in-line script documentation.

 

AI-assisted chart summary

Continuing with AI, next up we have the new AI-Assisted Chart Summary, which leverages generative AI to automatically generate concise, human-readable summaries of SAP Analytics Cloud charts embedded in your PowerPoint presentations. Whether you're preparing for a meeting or sharing insights with stakeholders, this feature helps you communicate key takeaways faster and more clearly.

 

 

AI-assisted commenting

Our third AI-assisted feature enables users to streamline efforts to summarize, translate, and interpret comments with the table and comment widget. This includes shortening and simplifying long-form commentary into highlights, summarizing data point comment threads and aggregating data point comments from descendant cells. These features will also translate this summarization and aggregation to the user’s language specified in their profile. When authoring a new comment, the user will have the ability to rephrase comments

 

Home Page renewal

This release introduces a new and improved home page for SAP Analytics Cloud users. New cards options, alongside existing ones, offer quick access to relevant tools, tasks, resources, and insights. They are available for users to quickly and easily personalize their home screen layout and features with minimal effort, further empowering them to create a tailored and efficient user experience. The new home screen aims to streamline workflows, increase productivity, and foster a stronger association with innovation and improved usability for SAP Analytics Cloud users.

Existing cards remain supported like data change insight, calendar tasks, recent files, and featured files, while new cards become available like just ask, on boarding, quick action, resources, and many more.

 

 

Optimized table experience

Inspired by numerous requests from our influence portal, this quarter we introduce a new optimized table experience.

The optimized table experience provides interface consistency with chart widgets and includes all features of classic tables. Additional functionality includes undo/redo options, mobile compatibility, expanded tooltip settings, improved data synchronization, and a new intuitive builder panel designed for customizing layouts, assigning dimensions, adding calculations, and filtering data. As this is a wide topic it covers 6 new innovations on the Roadmap explorer listed below:

  • Blending for a table with support of sort, rank, totals, and custom order
  • New builder panel
  • Option to turn on and off the Thresholds tooltip when hovering over a data cell in a table
  • New client calculations panel
  • New member selector
  • Sort and Rank enhancements

 

There are plenty more exciting deliverables coming your way this quarter and we will be taking a deeper dive into these items in our What’s New video and blog series so stay tuned. For a full list of all features coming in QRC3 2025 for SAP Analytics Cloud check out the Roadmap Explorer  and the What's New Viewer

Want to experience new and existing features for yourself? Take the leap and start your journey towards making data-driven decisions with confidence by signing up for a free trial, today.

entry.title: SAP 分析云 – 使用故事模版的最佳实践
entry.content:
本文系“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列之一，旨在协助用户借助 SAP 分析云设计并构建具有业务价值的仪表盘。   

 请点击此处，在新窗口中打开“仪表盘设计最佳实践”博客系列总览页。 

博客内容   

本文将详细说明以下内容：   

  1. 模板获取位置；   
  2. 模板自定义的分步操作指南；   
  3. 从零开始构建逻辑组的分步说明。 

在哪里查找模板？ 

请在此博客中查阅有关该 Horizon 模板的全部信息。

下方展示的是仅通过数次点击、利用该模板快速生成的示例故事。 

下一章节将为您详细说明如何对模板进行定制，以便迅速达成您的预期目标。 

模板自定义   

以下为分步操作指引，帮助您完成以下任务：   

  1. 向占位符添加内容；   
  2. 移除占位符并删除相应区段或微件；   
  3. 调整页面内容。 

1.向占位符添加内容；   

选中占位符中的按钮，在随后弹出的对话框内选择您想要使用的模型。 

添加所需的度量和维度。 

每个占位符均已预设特定统计图类型，但您仍可在“生成器”面板中按需更改。 

2. 移除占位符并删除区段或微件 

如需移除占位符，请先选中该占位符，点击右上角“···”图标，然后在上下文菜单中选择“删除”。由于底层采用自适应容器结构，其余内容将自动调整布局。 

如需删除模板中的整个区段，亦可通过“大纲”面板执行删除操作；删除后，布局将自动适配调整。 

3. 添加页面内容   

可通过多种方式向页面补充内容，最简单的方法是复制并粘贴现有内容，随后按需调整。 

分步示例：在逻辑组中复制并粘贴单个统计图   

  • 在“大纲”中，选中包含待复制统计图的面板。 

  • 使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + C，Mac 按 Command + C）或工具栏中的“复制”功能完成复制。随后，在“大纲”中选中您希望粘贴内容的目标区块。 
  • 粘贴时，请使用快捷键（Windows 按 Ctrl + V，Mac 按 Command + V）或工具栏中的“粘贴”功能。   

内容添加完毕后，您可在生成器或样式设置面板中对其进行进一步调整。 

示例 2：   

分步说明：复制现有逻辑组   

  • 选中包含待复制逻辑组的面板，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行复制操作。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴该逻辑组的区块，随后按照示例 1 所述方法执行粘贴操作。 

FlowLayoutPanel 会自动将新增的逻辑组向下排列。请注意：在同一层级的各个区块中，页面上的实际显示顺序为自上而下，但在“大纲”中的排列顺序则相反——即页面上位于最上方的内容，在大纲结构中显示在最下方。 

从零开始构建逻辑组 

步骤 1：创建新故事   

  • 登录您的 SAP Analytics Cloud 租户，选择“画布”。 

步骤 2：向页面添加面板   

  • 在工具栏中，依次选择“添加”按钮 > “容器” > “面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置参数设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 100%  、高度 = 400px 、左侧 = 0px 、右侧 = auto 、顶部 = 0px 、底部 = auto 

步骤 3：在现有面板中添加卡片面板   

  • 在第一层面板内再添加一块面板。   
  • 若需为此面板应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”处输入 card。  
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto 、高度 = auto 、左侧 = 16px 、右侧 = 16px 、顶部 = 16px 、底部 = 8px 

步骤 4：添加逻辑组标题面板   

  • 在上一步所建面板内再添加一块新面板，用于承载标题文本。   
  • 若需呈现视觉分隔效果，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__header。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = 48px  、左侧 = 0px  、右侧 = 0px  、顶部 = 0px  、底部 = auto   
  • 圆角半径设为 0px。 

步骤 5：向标题面板添加文本元素   

  • 选择“文本”并输入逻辑组名称。若需为标题文本应用 Fiori Horizon 主题，请在样式面板的“CSS 类名”字段中输入 logic-group__title。   
  • 尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 自定义  、顶部 = 10px  、底部 = 0px 

步骤 6：添加流式布局面板   

  • 选中 Panel_2，依次选择“容器” > “流式布局面板”。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将流式布局面板的尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = auto  、高度 = auto  、左侧 = 16px  、右侧 = 16px  、顶部 = 58px  、底部 = 8px 

步骤 7：添加统计图微件   

  • 在流式布局面板中插入一个统计图微件。 

  • 选择统计图类型，并为统计图定义所需的度量与维度。 

  • 在样式面板中，请将尺寸与位置设置如下：   
  • 宽度 = 50%  、高度 = 100% 

步骤 8：复制并粘贴统计图微件   

  • 选中需复制的统计图，使用工具栏中的“复制”功能，或按快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + C；Mac：Command + C）。 

  • 选中您希望粘贴统计图的流式布局面板。 

  • 请使用工具栏中的“粘贴”功能，或通过快捷键（Windows：Ctrl + V；Mac：Command + V）完成粘贴。 

  • 请再次选择统计图类型，并设定所需的度量与维度。 

若您需构建一个包含两个统计图微件的逻辑组，至此即可完成。 

如需在逻辑组中继续添加更多统计图，请重复上述步骤，并根据需要调整每张统计图的宽度。例如，若需并排展示三张统计图，请将每张统计图的宽度均设为 33%。 

结果 

恭喜！至此，您的逻辑组应已呈现类似下图所示的效果。
